School of Computer Science and Engineering, Nanyang Technological University 50 Nanyang Avenue Singapore 639798 Singapore Ground-source heat pumps are more energy-efficient, especially when compared to their water and air source counterparts. However, when operating and design conditions are vastly different, the expected gains in efficiency could be easily negated. Under such scenarios, measures to improve energy performance are explored through performing mathematical optimization on the appropriate model of the system. Components of a heat pump system are often operated at pre-defined setpoints or independently optimized, disregarding the overall performance. Formulation of a holistic optimization problem which expresses the system in its tuneable variables, while capturing the tight-coupling between its components results in a complex mixed-integer non-linear program. Our paper concerns itself with the mathematical modeling and optimization of the hourly operation of a ground-coupled heat pump system for improving energy and operating cost. We judiciously abstracted and decoupled the component models of the system, so that the problem could be formulated as a mixed-integer linear program. This vastly benefited the solvability of the optimization problem. For illustration, we implemented this methodology on a system in the ADREAM building of the LAAS-CNRS laboratory in Toulouse, France. Four case studies are defined in the lead up to holistic optimization, allowing the results to be easily understood. The results reveal significant limitations, which prompted the hybridization of the system with a hypothetical water-to-air heat exchanger. Results indicated electricity and cost savings of up to 35.0% and 12.7% respectively, depending on the objective function. Our findings postulate that the additional investment is recoverable within five years. Keywords Mixed integer linear program System modeling Holistic optimization Multi-time optimization Ground source heat pump Building integrated photovoltaics Electrical storage system 1 Introduction The popularity of ground-source heat pumps (GSHP) has been established in the recent years in response to the increasing regulations imposed by governing entities on energy consumption and implementation of Renewable Energies (RE) — due to the impact of climate change [1]. More specifically, in the European Union (EU), a policy framework has been released in order to ensure energy sustainability in the upcoming decade [2]. Enhanced efficiency due to a lower compressor-lift, is the primary reason for their increasing popularity [3,4]. After a certain depth, the temperature of the ground remains relatively invariant to ambient conditions, making it an ideal heat source or sink depending on the heating or cooling needs [5]. Given that space conditioning in buildings account for up to 13% of the global final energy use, any attempt to reduce this statistic could not be more welcomed [6]. The potential of GSHP system in reality, however, is often not fully realized owing to the difference in design and operating conditions [7]. Slow dissipation of thermal energy in the ground is a consequence of the inferior thermal conductivity of the soil. The outcome is the gradual degradation of the temperature and performance of the ground as a heat source or sink, which threatens to negate the only advantage of GSHPs. These issues are much more pronounced in regions dominated by either heating or cooling, as the ground is hardly left to fallow. Rigid control strategies based on pre-defined setpoints, or which are only concerned with maximizing efficiency at the component-level exacerbate these problems [8]. These measures disregard the cascading effect on the system level, thereby inhibiting the ability of the GSHP system to adapt appropriately under less desirable operating circumstances. Therefore, the focus of the current work is to comprehensively explore the solution space mapped by tuneable variables of GSHP system using mathematical optimization techniques. This allows us to gain insights into possible means of improving the system-level efficiency without the incurrence of high monetary costs. 1.1 Ground-source heat pump (GSHP) system A GSHP system leverages on thermal exchange with the ground for efficiency gains. Across the seasons, the difference between the comfortable room temperature and the ground is typically smaller than that of the ambient air. The smaller temperature difference reduces the mechanical load on the compressor of the heat pump, which translates into a superior efficiency when compared to traditional systems. Fig. 1.1 illustrates a GSHP system serving the architectures dynamiques reconfigurables pour systèmes embarqués autonomes mobiles (ADREAM) building of the Laboratoire d’analyze et d’architecture des systémes - Centre national de la recherche scientifique (LAAS-CNRS) laboratory. The ADREAM building hosts an experimental platform for optimized energy networks, building integrated photoVoltaics (BIPV) research, and smart grids, with the purpose of simulating zero-energy strategies according to the definitions of zero-energy buildings (ZEBs) [9]. Bore-hole heat exchangers are commonly used in systems of such scale to execute the thermal exchange with the ground. In cooling mode, hot water from the condensers of the heat pumps is circulated and cooled down by the ground. The reverse is true during heating mode. The regulation of flow direction to facilitate these configurations is done by the integration of two motorized valves. These heat exchangers usually are installed in parallel and drilled to a depth deep enough so that the ground temperature remains relatively uniform in spite of ambient conditions. Similar to existing GSHP systems, the heating and cooling production system of the ADREAM building is based on the combination of a heat pump and a geothermal system. The configuration of the thermal energy production system of the building can be summarized by Fig. 1.2. From Fig. 1.2, three reversible 45 kW heat pump units, are installed in order to provide the necessary heating and cooling load. The geothermal system connected to the heat pumps consists of 18 Double-U boreholes which reach 100 m of vertical ground depth. The diameter of the tubes is 0.16 m each. The thermal conductivity of the tubes towards the ground has a value of 1.95 W/mk, as calculated during the tests carried out before the construction of the building, for an average ground temperature of 16 ° C . 1.2 State of the art Designing a GSHP system using the popular rule-based methods yield errors ranging anywhere from −21% to 167%, primarily where the sizing of ground heat exchangers (GHE) is concerned [10,11]. Optimization work on the design of GSHP systems attempt to bridge this gap by utilizing models with higher precision to match the required cooling or heating demands [12,13]. Such studies try to determine the optimal configuration of equipment sizing such as the heat pump, piping network, with most of the attention paid to the design of GHEs [14,15]. Where complex multi-energy systems involving GSHPs are concerned, meta-heuristics are often found to be deployed in tandem with simulation-based software such as TRNSYS [16–18]. The deviation between the optimal design and performance will always exist in reality; as it is inevitable to make assumptions about operating conditions [19]. Optimization of GSHP operation entails a different set of requirements — models with higher fidelity and a problem formulation which has reasonable convergence speed [20,21]. Assumptions such as constant operating coefficients of performance ( C O P ) and temperatures of the heat pumps or ground, while they greatly simplify the optimization problem, serve little purpose for operation. Polynomial approximations of complex component models coupled with more robust optimization techniques offer a rational compromise between modeling accuracy and computational efficiency, hence are often deployed in model predictive control algorithms. It is well established that evaporating and condensing temperatures have a strong influence on the operating C O P s of heat pumps. Under specific scenarios, electricity savings of up to 28% could be achieved with the adjustments in space conditioning set-point temperatures [8]. Erosion of the gains in C O P s is often observed in GSHP systems due to the degradation of ground temperatures [7]. Hybridization of GSHP systems with alternative thermal exchange options, such as cooling towers, alleviate the burden on the ground and permits temperature recovery [22]. Various control strategies ranging from rule-based to the use of artificial neural networks (ANN) methods of toggling between GHEs and the available alternatives resulted in significant C O P improvements for these systems [23,24]. GSHP systems, just as heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems are also comprised of several energy-consuming components such as heat pump, pumps, and heat exchangers, working in tandem. It is not inconceivable for ancillary components to have a significant influence on system-level energy performance. Parallels had to be drawn from studies concerning the holistic optimization of the operation of closely-related systems due to the lack thereof, on GSHP systems [20]. For chiller systems serving commercial buildings, optimization involving ancillaries enabled additional energy savings of 6.5% [25]. The uncovering of counter-intuitive operating strategies which could only have resulted through the modeling of the tight-coupling between the main components and ancillaries of the system are clearly illustrated in [26,27]. It becomes evident from the review that a gap exists where the optimization of the operation of GSHP systems at the system-level is concerned. The few related studies prioritized the optimal performance of heat pumps for a given thermal load, neglecting the impact of ancillaries [20]. Hence, we can assume that as the complexity of systems increases, the interdependencies between components will naturally be more pronounced. Hence, the novelty of our current work are two-fold — the adaptation of the framework from our previous work for the hourly optimization of a GSHP system and demonstrating the importance of holistic optimization through the results of carefully selected case studies. 1.3 Objectives and contributions Two essential criteria have to be met for the results of the optimization study to be useful — the expression of decision variables which are tuneable in reality, and the modeling of interactions between the critical components of the GSHP system. The same cooling or heating demand could be fulfilled by countless combinations of component setpoints, each with a different impact on global system-level efficiency. Non-linearities inherent within the governing equations of the component models (heat pump, pump, ground heat exchanger) further compounds the complexity of the ensuing optimization problem. Categorical denial of existent scenarios whereby a compromise on the efficiencies of some components of the GSHP system, for enhanced system-level efficiency prunes the already restricted solution space of the problem through the introduction of unnecessary constraints. This explains why component-level optimization is less impactful than the holistic approach for operation purposes. As a pre-requisite to the formulation of the optimization problem, we first identified and models which appropriately expresses the workings of each component of the GSHP system as a function of tuneable variables (flowrate, temperature setpoint, pressure). Subsequently, we abstracted the models in a fashion whereby the resultant formulation is compatible with the framework developed for holistic optimization of a similar system type — a key feature of our previous work [27]. We prudently balanced the fidelity of the models with the compatibility for optimization. For illustrative purposes, we applied our optimization strategy to several case studies based on an existing GSHP system from the ADREAM building in Toulouse. Our final formulation of the optimization problem exploited features which are case study specific — effectively simplifying the optimization into a mixed-integer linear program (MILP). Doing so, abolished the need for the metaheuristic, improves the solvability of the problem. Problem solvability is improved as mathematical programming solvers are generally much more capable of dealing with a larger quantity of variables and constraints, most notably the latter — it is usually difficult representing constraints using metaheuristics other than representing them by penalizing the objective function. The reformulation of problem in our case into a MILP is crucial for the problem to be solved, especially given that the problem we are trying to optimize is a one that is multi-system and multi-time, with the variable and constriant count well into the tens of thousands. Throughout the four case studies defined, we progressively added a single component at a time to the optimization problem and investigated its impact on either of the objective functions defined — total electricity consumption or operating cost. Through the results of the case studies, we explicitly observed the merits of modeling the tight-coupling amongst the components in the GSHP system and holistically optimization. Finally, our findings suggest that hybridizing the GSHP system with a theoretical water-to-air heat exchanger as an alternative to thermal exchange with the ground could result in electricity and cost savings of up to 12.7% and 35% over a year. The concise formulation of the multi-time optimization problem, the concomitant implementation on an existing GSHP system and the insights acquired over the four case studies defined are the primary contributions of our paper. 1.4 Organization of the paper We present the GSHP system to be optimized in the next section. Section 3 details the models selected to represent the system’s components and the accompanying abstraction process required, for compatibility with mathematical optimization. We subsequently formulated the entailing problem in Section 4. Finally, we discuss and analyze the results generated from our case studies. 2 Case study description Case studies formulated in this paper are based on a functioning GSHP system serving a laboratory in Toulouse (Fig. 1.1). This laboratory is part of the ADREAM project which focuses on the collective optimization of smart-grids, BIPV, HVAC and ambient cyber–physical systems [28]. Simulations studies on the GSHP system of interest have since been conducted to identify areas for energy savings manually [29]. Our current work is an extension of these studies through the lens of mathematical optimization performed at the system-level. Analysis of data collected through the numerous sensors installed around the laboratory revealed two key areas to address for improving the energy performance of the GSHP system — improving the operation of the hydronic network and the ground temperatures. Inferior evaporating and condensing temperatures in the winter and summer respectively, appeared to adequately explain the deviation between the theoretical and actual efficiencies of the heat pumps. This suggests that GHEs are likely to have been undersized. Additionally, the rule-based operation inhibited the adaptability of the system for less-than-ideal scenarios. Therefore, the case studies defined in this paper attempt to utilize potential improvements in operating practices for enhanced energy performance. We deploy an adaptation of the optimization framework for this undertaking [27]. Nomenclature of terms used in this paper are detailed in Table 2.1. Fig. 1.2 illustrates the GSHP system serving the laboratory. It comprises of 3 identical heat pumps serving a total of 5 zones of various usage (office, server rooms, laboratories). Depending on the season, the 18 borehole heat exchangers function as either a heat sink or source. The entire GSHP system could be powered by electricity from any combination of the three sources — grid, battery or directly from solar photovoltaics (Fig. 1.1). In the following two subsections, we define case studies to address the two identified issues and discuss the management of the input data used. These lay the foundation for selecting the appropriate models and eventually formulate the optimization problem, which we delve into greater detail in Section 3. 2.1 Description of the chosen case studies With the improvement of the hydronic network and ground temperature performances listed as primary objectives, we defined four case studies. These case studies are chosen to progressively optimize the energy performance of the GSHP system so that the final result will be better assimilated. Optimization, when performed at the system-level, tend to lead to results that are not easily interpretable due to the amalgamation of non-linearities in, and conflicting interactions among the sub-systems. Therefore, the four case studies defined in this paper are designed to walk the reader through the isolated effects of optimization on individual components by incrementally increasing the size of the optimization problem, i.e., case study 1 only optimizes the hydronic network, solar and batteries were introduced in case study 2, heat pumps are then introduced in the ensuing case studies. An alternative thermal exchange option had to be added to the system to reduce the degradation of the ground temperatures (Fig. 2.1). For that, we chose a water-to-air heat exchanger to enable the heat pumps to interact with the ambient air, thermally. Consequently, we had to explore avenues to justify the added monetary investment through the inclusion of battery operation and costs objectives to the optimization problem. Hence, our final model had to include heat pumps (HP), evaporator and condenser pumps (EP, CP), distribution pumps (DP), GHEs, water-to-air heat exchangers (WAHX), solar photovoltaics (PV), grid electricity (GE) and battery (Batt) for electricity storage. Three base ( b c ) and four optimization cases ( o p t ) form the basis of our case studies. Table 2.2 documents the base and optimization cases at the component level. Table 2.3 describes the objective of each case study defined in this paper. 2.2 Management of input data Ambient and demand conditions are the input data to the optimization problem. For the purpose of the case study, the two following simplifications were made. 1. Aggregation of rooms to zones. The laboratory comprises of 36 rooms which are summarized into five zones, grouped by the similarity of their demand profiles. 2. Usage of typical days to approximate monthly conditions. Every month of the year is represented by a single 24-hour day thermal demand and ambient condition profile. The cumulative thermal demand of the chosen days used for each month is documented in Fig. 2.2. The ambient conditions ( T a m b and G i ω ) were then used to calculate the available electricity generated using the BIPV model, as shown in Fig. 2.3. Variation in cloud coverage, in combination with the degradation of solar panel efficiencies with ambient temperatures are likely to account for the unexpected dips in the solar power generated during the months of August and October. The simplifications made in the input data drastically reduces the resolution time required for the solvers. Since the main purpose of our paper is to illustrate the benefits of performing holistic optimization on the GSHP system, such approximations are still applicable as they do not mask the trends we intend to highlight (Section 5). We used hourly data as input to our case studies. Hourly electricity pricing data was also used as input for the case study. There are six pricing tiers, which differ according to the month of the year and the hour of the day (Fig. 2.4). 3 Model selection and abstraction Required models of each component found in the GSHP system described in Fig. 1.2 and the corresponding abstraction procedure is discussed in this section. We prefer equation-based models because of the balanced trade-off between accuracy and mathematical optimization compatibility. We attempt to linearize the models as much as possible so that the resultant formulation is more congruous with the MILP format. All component models were formulated to minimize electricity ( E ̇ ). The operating cost can be easily determined by multiplying the hourly electricity consumption by the specific unit cost of electricity for the given hour ( E ̇ e l e _ r a t e ). All temporary parameters slated will be addressed in Section 4. 3.1 Heat pump Heat pumps transfer thermal energy by extracting and rejecting heat at the evaporator and condenser respectively. This model maps the relationship between the temperature and flowrate variables on both the evaporator and condenser of the heat pump to electricity consumption. We selected a quasi-empirical model developed by Gordon and Ng to represent the required relationship [9]. The empirical aspect of this model enabled us to calibrate it with raw data. Since this model is established using the laws of thermodynamics, it exhibits relatively good predictive performance in spite of limited data points [30–32]. The ensuing procedure describes our abstraction of the heat pump model in cooling mode. The same procedure is used for calculation in heating mode. The governing equation for the Gordon-Ng universal (GNU) model is shown in Eq. (3.1). Together with the C O P and steady-flow energy equations (SFEE) applied on the evaporators and condensers, the electricity consumption of the heat pump could be directly expressed in terms of its tuneable variables such as flowrate and temperatures (Eqs. (3.2)–(3.5)). We added a coefficient α 0 in Eq. (3.5) to improve the consistency with raw data, and to account for additional losses which are not yet accounted for. For our case, the value of α 0 is 0.94. For such factors to be considered, we employed analytical equations to model the relationship between the pump and network [34]. Pump(s) and the piping network which they are connected to, must be modeled simultaneously as they are highly dependent. In this case, it permits the thermal exchange between the evaporator/condenser of the heat pump to the ambient air. To model the WAHX, we used the Log-Mean-Temperature-Difference equation governing crossflow heat exchangers alongside SFEEs [40]. For illustration purposes, Eqs. (3.23) to (3.25) represent the WAHX functioning as a air-cooled condenser for the heat pump in cooling mode. We utilized the optimization framework developed in [27] together with the component models described in the previous section for the undertaking. Depending on the optimization cases defined in Table 2.2 the objective function could either be the minimization of total operating cost ( C E ̇ ) or electricity consumption ( E ̇ ). In the following two subsections, we first determine the treatment of parameters and variables of the GSHP system before formulating the optimization problem. We then discuss the error incurred in the models we selected, and our simulation of the defined base cases. 4.1 Parameters and variables The fidelity of the component models selected enables a degree of freedom higher than required for our GSHP system. We attempt to simplify the problem formulation by only optimizing the tuneable variables of the system. Methods chosen to reduce the models into MILP-compatible formats which include discretization, piecewise linearization, regression and the ‘reformulation-linearization-technique’ have been discussed in Section 3. Some of the decision variables must be treated as temporary parameters so that the ensuing optimization problem is compatible with the MILP format. Table 4.1 details the treatment of the temporary parameters (Section 3) of the selected component models, specific to the GSHP system in the case study. In cases where the temporary parameter is required to be treated as a decision variable in the optimization problem, we discretize them, creating several sub-models of the same component. We then introduced constraints so that only one of the sub-models could be ‘activated’ at any given point in time. This ensures that the affected decision variable can still be treated as a temporary parameter in the sub-model, making the chosen abstraction methods relevant and the resultant problem formulation compatible with the MILP format. The choice of sub-models to be ‘activated’ at any given point, yields the optimal value of the discretized decision variable. Three identical heat pumps, coupled with non-adjustable flowrates on the evaporator and condenser sides allows the further simplification of the optimization problem by exploiting the equal-load distribution operating strategy (ELD) [42]. The exploitation of the ELD strategy and the treatment of the temporary parameters enabled the optimization problem to be reduced entirely to a MILP. Variables and parameters of a single time-step (1-hour), before the abstraction, are detailed in Table 4.2. 4.2 Mathematical formulation In our case studies, we either optimized the GSHP system with respect to the total electricity consumed ( E ̇ ) or total operating cost ( C E ̇ ). Both objective functions comprise of terms from all components of the system, namely the water-to-air heat exchanged ( W A H X ), distribution pump ( d i s t , p ), evaporator pump ( e , p ), condenser pump ( c , p ), heat pump ( h p ) and batteries ( b a t t ). The two objective functions are: (4.1) m i n i m i z e E ̇ = ∑ t = 1 m [ E ̇ W A H X , t + E ̇ d i s t , p , t + ∑ i 3 E ̇ e , p , t + ∑ i 3 E ̇ c , p , t ∑ i = 1 3 E ̇ h p , i , t + ∑ i = 1 p w l ( 1 − η b a t t , i ) E ̇ b a t t , i , t i n ] (4.2) m i n i m i z e C E ̇ = ∑ t = 1 m E e l e _ r a t e , t × [ E ̇ W A H X , t + E ̇ d i s t , p , t + ∑ i 3 E ̇ e , p , t + ∑ i 3 E ̇ c , p , t + ∑ i = 1 3 E ̇ h p , i , t + ∑ i = 1 p w l ( 1 − η b a t t , i ) E ̇ b a t t , i , t i n ] Equations of the abstracted models discussed in Section 3, serve as constraints in problem formulation. The discretization of T e i n or T c i n and parameterization of m ̇ c and m ̇ e allows the electricity consumed by the heat pump to be expressed as: (4.3) E ̇ h p , i = f ( T e , i i n , T e , i o u t , T c , i i n ) Since the flowrate of the evaporator and condenser pumps are constants, E ̇ e , p , i and E ̇ c , p , i will undertake only constant or null values depending whether the optimizer chooses to have them activated. Electricity consumed by the distribution pump is not only dependent on the total flowrate through the hydronic network by also the pressure difference — determined partially by the regulation of valves implicit to the pump and network model. The electricity consumed by the distribution pump is: (4.4) E ̇ d i s t , p = f ( m ̇ z , 1 , … , m ̇ z , 5 ) Constant m ̇ e and m ̇ c values result in m ̇ w also being a constant. Additionally fixing the approach temperature ( T a p p ), allows the following expression: (4.5) E ̇ W A H X = f ( m ̇ a ) The final term ( 1 − η b a t t , i ) E ̇ b a t t , i , t i n , is included to account for losses incurred during the charging process of the battery. Additional model-specific constraints listed in Table 4.2 are not discussed here. Similarly, the constraints utilized for facilitating interactions between the component models can be found in [27]. Finally, the bounds the decision variables are documented in Table 4.3. 4.3 Modeling error We used 75% and 25% of the processed data for training and evaluating the models respectively (Figs. 4.1 and 4.2). The mean absolute error for the models representing the heat pump and distribution pump are 4.79% and 11.27% respectively. Similar values were posted for the evaporator and condenser pumps. For the pumps, we found the chief causes of inaccuracies to be the from the sensor readings and data aggregation over the hourly time-horizon. Despite so, the fidelity of the models to performance in reality, is preserved. 4.4 Simulation of base cases The base cases defined in Section 2.1 are also simulated using the models which we have chosen. This serves as a fair benchmark for the evaluation of the optimal results obtained. 4.5 Solver and hyperparameters All computations were done on a workstation with 16 GB of RAM and an i7 4710HQ CPU clocked at 3.5 GHz on all cores. The MILP problem was solved using Gurobi version 7.0.2. An average run takes approximately 5 s to converge under the default criteria where the tolerance of 10−5 was met. 5 Results and discussion For each of the four case studies, we first present a comparison of the results of the base and optimization cases for each of the 12 days selected to represent the year. Subsequently, we attempt to explain our findings by using the results from a selected representative day as an example. 5.1 Case study 1: Energy optimization of the hydronic network This case study focuses on the operation of distribution pumps in the hydronic network. Fig. 5.1 illustrates the electricity consumption of the distribution pumps operating under three different control strategies — constant speed, variable speed, and optimized pressure setpoint. The switch from constant speed pumps to variable speed pumps could potentially result in electricity savings of about 19.8%. The bulk of these savings is attributed to the ability for the speed of the pump to be automatically adjusted in tandem with the flowrate demands. However, variable speed pumps are typically operated at a pre-determined pressure setpoint, which is determined through an estimate of a pressure differential which can deliver the required flowrate for the highest demand of a given period. By adapting the pressure setpoint in response to the hourly flowrate requirement, additional electricity savings could of 63.16% result. Using a typical day in July as an example (Fig. 5.2), the pressure setpoint of the variable speed pump is relatively too high for large periods of the day. While it is understandable that the setpoint is determined by the peak demand of a given period, considerable savings will result if it could be adapted according to demand, especially during the wee hours’ of the day. 5.2 Case study 2: Operation cost optimization Batteries in our GSHP system exist for storing excess solar energy which could not be fully utilized. However, more could be done with these batteries — storing electricity from the grid when the price is favorable. The cost-saving potential exists in such a measure. We attempt to optimize the operating cost by allowing the optimizer to also store electricity from the grid when the price is low. Fig. 5.3 illustrates the potential monthly cost savings between the two battery operating strategies — storing only when there is excess solar energy and optimized battery storage which also permits storing electricity from the grid. For a given year, approximately 12.73% of the current operating cost could be reduced. The difference in battery operation is clearly illustrated in Fig. 5.4. Electricity was drawn from the grid to be stored in the battery at 0300 and 0700 h, just before the spike in electricity pricing occurred. This is the primary reason for the cost savings. Other differences in battery operation are inconsequential as they occur when the electricity price remained constant. Storage of electricity from the grid is a difficult decision as it involves determining the trade-off among the losses due to battery charging inefficiencies, cost savings, and future electricity demand, thus, best left to an optimizer. 5.3 Case study 3: Energy optimization including WAHX We identify one of the key bottlenecks to our GSHP system when holistic optimization was applied. It is difficult to significantly improve the energy performance of the GSHP system as the heat pumps are consistently subjected to unfavorable ground temperatures for prolonged periods. This implies a possible under sizing of the GHE for the system. The only possible way to improve operating temperatures of the heat pumps is to provide an alternative to the GHE, hence we introduce a theoretical WAHX to the system. Fig. 5.5 compares the average monthly electricity savings when the operations of the hybrid GSHP system is holistically optimized ( o p t 3 ) as compared to the current state ( b c 3 ). Electricity savings across the year averaged at 12.71%. The greatest savings occurred during the months where the thermal (cooling) demand was the highest. We delve into the daily operation of a typical day in July to unveil the reasons behind the electricity savings (Fig. 5.6). Without an alternative for the GHE, recovery of the ground temperatures for b c 3 becomes impossible and begins to rise until it hits a plateau. 33 ° C is a relatively high condensing temperature for the heat pumps considering that the ambient air temperature is lower. Under the operating strategy provided by o p t 3 , the WAHX is activated whenever the ground temperature starts to rise. By dissipating the condenser heat into the ambient air instead of the ground, it enabled the ground temperature to gradually recover to its initial state. The WAHX is typically an inferior alternative to the GHE for the two ensuing reasons — additional electrical consumption from fans and less favorable condensing temperatures as they are dependent on ambient air temperatures. This is most evident during 0700, 1400 and 1700 h where the optimal operation consumed more electricity than current practice. It was a necessary sacrifice for the benefit of the enhanced overall performance of the day, because it enables heat to be dissipated from the ground naturally (Fig. 5.8). The corresponding system C O P is plotted in Fig. 5.7. The limits of the hybrid GSHP system is apparent towards the final hours of the day, where in spite of superior condensing temperatures, the COP of the system only posted marginal improvements due to the heat pumps being operated at extremely low part-load conditions. It is also to be noted that levels of C O P suggested by the model especially between 0800 and 1000 h is unlikely to be exact due to extrapolation of the model outside the dataset shown in Fig. 4.1 — that said, given the models used in the case study are derived from first principles, we strongly believe that the exhibited trend will persist. 5.4 Case study 4: Operation cost optimization including WAHX Adding a WAHX to the GSHP system will require monetary investment, and thus should be justified with the savings from operation cost. In this case study, we provide a comparison of a holistically optimized hybrid GSHP system for two objectives; electricity consumption and operating cost against the current state. Fig. 5.9 details the monthly average operating cost under three different cases b c 3 , o p t 3 and o p t 4 . While there exist considerable cost savings when the GSHP system was optimized for electricity consumption, an additional 28.17% could be realized, when instead optimized for the minimization of operating costs. The explanation for this additional savings becomes evident when we delve deeply into the optimized results for any given day. We use a typical day in July as an example for discussion purposes. The difference in battery operation could probably explain the difference in operating cost between o p t 3 and o p t 4 . As shown in Fig. 5.10, the excess electricity from solar photovoltaics is never stored in the batteries in o p t 3 , where we minimize the total electricity consumption. Storage of electrical energy in batteries incur losses during the charging process, thus abstained from in o p t 3 . However, with operating cost as the objective function, it then became necessary to store not only the excess electricity from solar photovoltaics but also electricity from the grid when the price is considerably lower — as it can be used to supplement electrical demands when the price increases. This additional electricity stored, influenced the operation of the hybrid GSHP system in terms of electrical consumption — the inconsequential poorer efficiencies during periods of excess electricity 0400–0800 h, and the considerably better performance during periods where electricity price is high (Figs. 5.11 and 5.12). There even exist scenarios where the WAHX was activated just before the sharp increase in electricity price as shown in Fig. 5.11 at 1100 h. This was likely done to improve the C O P of the heat pumps when the electricity price is higher. Accounting for the trade-off between components of a tightly-coupled system is complex, and non-intuitive, thereby highlighting the benefit of performing optimization. From our survey, a typical WAHX suitable for our GSHP system is priced at approximately 25 000 €. Optimization results indicate potential cost savings of about 5600 € when o p t 4 is compared to b c 3 , calculated based on the electricity pricing structure found in Fig. 2.4. This indicates roughly that the payback period is likely to occur under five years. Finally, we included a plot of the break down of electricity consumption across all the cases used in the case studies in Fig. 5.13. The components operated differently as more components were added to the optimization problem, demonstrating the benefit of performing optimization holistically and giving consideration to the tight-coupling between them. This is evidenced when comparing the optimization problems of identical objective functions with each other, i.e., o p t 3 versus o p t 1 and o p t 4 versus o p t 2 . When the system was optimized holistically, an additional 6.52% and 5.59% of electricity can be saved moving from o p t 1 to o p t 3 and o p t 2 to o p t 4 respectively. These savings was primarily derived from evaporator and condenser pumps which were less constraint when the heat pumps were introduced as decision variables into the formulation, clearly illustrating the importance of system-level optimization. Finally, we also note the optimization of operating cost does not correspondingly lead to the best energy performance, as evidenced by o p t 3 and o p t 4 . 6 Conclusion The incongruity between design and operating conditions of ground-coupled heat pump systems will always exist due to imperfection in available data. We adapted an optimization framework for guiding potential improvements in ground-coupled heat pump systems in this paper. Our framework utilized abstracted models of critical components of ground-coupled heat pump systems which were sufficiently accurate yet provide compatibility with the mixed-integer linear program, vastly benefiting the solvability of the resulting optimization problem. For enhancing the appreciation of holistic optimization, we formulated four case studies to progressively optimize a ground-coupled heat pump system which is based on an actual system serving a laboratory. Through the analysis of results from the case studies, we identified two key areas of electricity savings — operation of the hydronic network and the improvement of ground temperatures. We addressed the thermal degradation of the ground by hybridizing the ground-coupled heat pump system with a water-to-air heat exchanger. Optimized results indicate potential electricity and cost savings of up to 12.7% and 35% respectively. With that, return on investment of the water-to-air heat exchanger is expected to be under five years. Such levels of savings would not have been possible without consideration of the tight-coupling between the components and holistic optimization. At its core, our framework aims to provide prototype and optimization solutions for buildings with configurable system installations. Its essence lies in the modeling and corresponding optimization technique. Moving away from the scientific lens, our work also responds directly to the European Union target for building energy consumption reduction of 40% by 2030. In France, the tertiary decree in vigor, requires buildings to urgently document their energy consumptions and implement energy optimization strategies. Our framework potentially provides the appropriate procedures and solutions for large and small scale buildings. Currently, our implementation considers a rather simplistic input of the thermal demands. Further inclusion of better estimates of cooling and heating demands by modeling the thermal envelope and air circulation or rooms will make our results more conclusive. This underpins our future work. CRediT authorship contribution statement Zhonglin Chiam: Conception and design of study, Analysis and/or interpretation of data, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Ground-source heat pumps are more energy-efficient, especially when compared to their water and air source counterparts. However, when operating and design conditions are vastly different, the expected gains in efficiency could be easily negated. Under such scenarios, measures to improve energy performance are explored through performing mathematical optimization on the appropriate model of the system. Components of a heat pump system are often operated at pre-defined setpoints or independently optimized, disregarding the overall performance. Formulation of a holistic optimization problem which expresses the system in its tuneable variables, while capturing the tight-coupling between its components results in a complex mixed-integer non-linear program. Our paper concerns itself with the mathematical modeling and optimization of the hourly operation of a ground-coupled heat pump system for improving energy and operating cost. We judiciously abstracted and decoupled the component models of the system, so that the problem could be formulated as a mixed-integer linear program. This vastly benefited the solvability of the optimization problem. For illustration, we implemented this methodology on a system in the ADREAM building of the LAAS-CNRS laboratory in Toulouse, France. Four case studies are defined in the lead up to holistic optimization, allowing the results to be easily understood. The results reveal significant limitations, which prompted the hybridization of the system with a hypothetical water-to-air heat exchanger. Results indicated electricity and cost savings of up to 35.0% and 12.7% respectively, depending on the objective function. Our findings postulate that the additional investment is recoverable within five years.
coredata.dc:title: Holistic optimization of the operation of a GCHP system: A case study on the ADREAM building in Toulouse, France
